Abstract: Arts & Ideas looks ahead at works-in-progress; Dr Nicholas M Barbaro and team at University of California at San Francisco joins with epilepsy specialists at Yale, Pittsburgh, Northwestern and Virginia universities to study bloodless radiosurgery technique to help patients with temporal lobe epilepsy, which is drug-resistant but is responsive to traditional surgery; $5-million Gamma Knife developed in Sweden focuses low-dosage gamma radiation on brain target; photo (M)
Snippet: Arts & Ideas looks ahead at works-in-progress; Dr Nicholas M Barbaro and team at University of California at San Francisco joins with epilepsy specialists at Yale, Pittsburgh, Northwestern and Virginia universities to study bloodless radiosurgery ...
LeadParagraph: The centruy's turn has been a time of retrospectives: what was the most important event, who was the most influential thinker? Arts & Ideas decided to take a look ahead at what some of today's researchers are working on. From the most raked-over field, like the history of the ancient world, to the latest medical technology, scholars are coming up with fresh insights. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs, and others may turn out to be dead-ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

Headline.Main: Works In Progress From All Over; Bloodless Knife for Epilepsy
Headline.PrintHeadline: Works In Progress From All Over; Bloodless Knife for Epilepsy
